arXiv:gr-qc/0306060v2 16 Jul 2007

Introduction to Bosonic String Theory
Eduard Alexis Larrañaga Rubio
Bogotá, D.C. November 2002

iii

iv

CONTENTS

Introduction
The development of fundamental physics in the past century arose from the
identification and the overcoming of contradictions between the existing ideas.
Fro example, the incompatibility of Maxwell’s equations and Galilean invariance
led Einstein to create the Special Theory of Relativity, and the inconsistency
of this ones with Newtonian gravity produced the General Theory of Relativity. Same thing happend with the conciliation between special relativity and
quantum mechanics, wich led to the development of Quantum Field Theory.
Now, there is another incompatibility: General Relativity and Quantum
Field theory. The quantization of gravity seems to be a non-renormalizable
theory.
In the past year, String Theory has been the leading candidate for a theory
that unifies all fundamental forces in nature in a consistent scheme. The way
that string theory does this is to give up one of the basic assumptions of quantum
field theory, that elementary particles are mathematical points, and instead
to develop aquantum field theory of one-dimensional extended objects, called
strings.
Ths string theory is still in progress, and there is not yet a complete description of the standard model of elementary particles based on it. However, there
are some important features that seems to be gnereic in every kind of string
theory: The first, and most important, is that general relativity is already incorporated in the theory. Although ordinary quantum field theory does not
allow gravity, string theory requires it. The second fact is that the Yang-Mills
gauge theories of the sort that comprise the standard model naturally arise in
string theory, but there is not yet a fully understanding of why should we prefer
the specific SU (3) ⊗ SU (2) ⊗ U (1) gauge theory.
Here is given a little introduction to the most basic string theory: th bosonic
string. First there is given the basics of the classical string theory as a generalization of the concept of world-line of a particle. Then the bosonic string is
constructed and the oscillation modes are described. The covariant canonical
quantization procedure is used and the bosonic spectra is shown.

v

vi

INTRODUCTION

Chapter 1

Classical String Theory
1.1

World-Line of a Point Particle

Classically, a point particle follow a trajectory in space time that is called ’worldline’. The world line can be expressed as functions xµ (τ ) with a parameter τ.
The path is an extremal of the action, that for a point particle of mass m is
proportional to the length of the world line:
Z
Z q
.µ.v
−ηµν x x dτ
(1.1)
S = m ds = m
where ηµν is the flat Minkowski space-time metric. The momentum conjugate to xµ (τ ) is:

pµ = −

∂L
.µ = −
∂x


 q
.µ.
∂ m −x xµ
.µ

.

xµ

−x

.µ.
−x xµ

(1.2)

(1.3)

This equation gives the constrain of mass-shell:
p2 = −m2

(1.4)

The Lagrange equation from varying S with respect to x (τ ) is:
∂L
∂

∂xµ
∂τ

(1.8)

So, Hcan vanishes identically. This means that the constrain given in (1.4)
governs the dynamics of the system completly. This constrain can be added to
the Hamiltonian by using a Lagrange multiplier. This gives:
H=

(1.12)

i.e. we are describing time-like trajectories.
The action in (1.1) is invariant under local reparametrizations. This kind of
gauge invariance is represented by a change τ −→ τ (e
τ ). This reparametrization
invariance is a one-dimensional analog of the four dimensional general coordinate
invariance. The choice N = 1 corresponds to the called ”static gauge”:
x0 = τ
And in this gauge the action becomes:
Z p

1.1.1

Alternative Action for a point particle

An alternative action for the point particle is:
Z

1 
.µ .v
S=−
ηµν x x e−1 (τ ) − m2 e (τ ) dτ
2

(1.18)

where e (τ ) (called the ’einbein’) is a new independient function. This action
allows to make the generalization to the massless case, and doesn’t have square
roots like in (1.1) that makes the treatment of the quantum theory complicated.
In order to prove that the action are equivalent, lets make the variation of e (τ ):
Z

5

1.2. WORLD-VOLUME ACTION

1.2

World-Volume Action

As we have seen, the action for a point particle was proportional to the lenght
of its world-line. For strings, the action will be prportional to the surface
area of its world-sheet, and in general for a p−brane the action involves the
(p + 1) −dimensional volume:
Z
S = −Tp dµp+1
(1.32)

where the constant Tp makes the action dimensionless, so it has dimensions
of [mass](p+1) or [lenght]−(p+1) . This factor is asociated with the tension of
the p−brane. For a 0− brane, (i.e. a point particle) it is just the mass.

Suppose that ξ α (α = 0, 1, 2, ..., p + 1) are the coordinates in the worldvolume of the p−brane, and gµν (µ, ν = 0, 1, 2, ...., d − 1) is the metric of the
d−dimensional space-time in which the p−brane propagates. Then, gµν induces
a metric in the world-volume given by:
ds2 = −gµν dxµ dxν = −gµν

∂xµ ∂xν α β
dξ dξ = Gαβ dξ α dξ β
∂ξ α ∂ξ β

(1.33)

where the induced metric is:
Gαβ = −gµν

∂xµ ∂xν
∂ξ α ∂ξ β

(1.34)

Then, the invariant volume element is given by:
dµp+1 =

1.3

p
− det Gαβ dp+1 ξ

(1.35)

Nambu-Goto Action

In the case of 1−branes, i.e. strings, the world-volume action (1.32) becomes:
Z p
S = −T
− det Gαβ d2 ξ
(1.36)
If the space-time is flat Minkowski gµν = ηµν we have:
s


p
∂xµ ∂xν
− det Gαβ = − det −ηµν α β
∂ξ ∂ξ
Defining ξ 0 = τ and ξ 1 = σ, then:

(1.37)

6

CHAPTER 1. CLASSICAL STRING THEORY

where:

q
p
2 . 2
.
− det Gαβ =
x · x′ − x x′2
.

x=

∂x
∂τ

x′ =

(1.38)

∂x
∂σ

(1.39)

and the action for the string, called Nambu-Goto action becomes:
Z q
2 . 2
.
SN G = −T
x · x′ − x x′2 dσdτ

1.4

(1.40)

Polyakov Action

Again, as in the point particle case, the square root in the Nambu-Goto action make the quantum treatment complicated. So, we introduce an equivalent
action:
Z
p
T
− det hαβ hαβ ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν d2 ξ
(1.41)
SP = −
2
µ

where hαβ (σ, τ ) is the world-sheet metric and ∂α xµ = ∂x
∂ξ α . The stress-tensor
is defined as the variation of the action with respect to the metric:
Tαβ ≡ −

1
2
δS
p
T − det hαβ δhαβ

1
Tαβ = ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν − hαβ hγδ ηµν ∂γ xµ ∂δ xν
2

(1.42)
(1.43)

Hence, the Euler-Lagrange equation is:
1
∂α x · ∂β x − hαβ hγδ ∂γ x · ∂δ x = 0
2

(1.44)

Solving for hαβ we obtain:
hαβ = ∂α x · ∂β x = ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν

(1.45)

Substituing this in (1.44) gives:
1
1
hαβ − hαβ hγδ hγδ = hαβ − hαβ δγγ = hαβ − hαβ = 0
2
2

(1.46)

1.5. SYMMETRIES OF THE POLYAKOV ACTION

7

So, (1.45) means that the metric in the world-sheet hαβ is equal (at least
classically) to the induced metric. Substituing this in the Polyakov action we
obtain:
Z q
T
− det (ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν )hαβ hαβ d2 ξ
(1.47)
SP = −
2
Z q
T
− det (ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν )δαα d2 ξ
(1.48)
SP = −
2
Z q
(1.49)
SP = −T
− det (ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν )d2 ξ = SN G
Hence the Polyakov and the Nambu-Goto actions are equivalent, at least
classically, since in the quantum treatment it is not in general.

1.5

Symmetries of the Polyakov Action

Polyakov action has the symmetries:
1. Poincaré invariance:
xµ 7−→ ω µν xν + aµ

,

hαβ 7−→ hαβ

(1.50)

with ωµν = −ωνµ .
2. Local 2-dimensional reparametrization invariance
ξ α 7−→ ξ ′α ξ β
3. Conformal or Weyl invariance
hαβ 7−→ Λ (ξ γ ) hαβ

,



(1.51)

xµ = xµ

(1.52)

The two reparametrization invariance symmetries of S allow us to choose a
gauge in which the three independient components of hαβ are expressed with
just one function. The usual choose is th conformal flat gauge:
hαβ = eΛ(ξ) ηαβ


(1.53)


−1 0
is the 2-dimensional Minkowski metric for a flat
0 1
world-sheet. Substituing this in the action que obtain:
where ηαβ =

8

CHAPTER 1. CLASSICAL STRING THEORY

S=−

T
2

Z q

− det eΛ(ξ) ηαβ e−Λ(ξ) η αβ ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν d2 ξ
S=−

T
2

Z p
e2Λ(ξ) e−Λ(ξ) η αβ ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν d2 ξ

S=−

T
2

Z

η αβ ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν d2 ξ

(1.54)

(1.55)

(1.56)

As can be seen, the gauge fixed action is quadratic in the x’s. Thus, mathematically it is the same as a theory of d free scalar fields in two dimensions.
Varying xµ we obtain the equation of motion:
.. µ

x − x′′µ = 0

(1.57)

This is simply a free two dimensional wave equation. Also, we have to take
account of the constraints Tαβ = 0. In the conformal gauge this constrain is:
1
Tαβ = ηµν ∂α xµ ∂β xν − ηαβ η γδ ηµν ∂γ xµ ∂δ xν = 0
2

(1.58)

This can be writen as:
1
.µ.ν
T00 = ηµν x x + η γδ ηµν ∂γ xµ ∂δ xν = 0
2

(1.59)

1
1
.µ .ν
.µ.ν
T00 = ηµν x x − ηµν x x + ηµν x′µ x′ν = 0
2
2

(1.60)

T00 = T11 =


1
.µ.ν
ηµν x x + ηµν x′µ x′ν = 0
2
.µ

T01 = T10 = ηµν x x′ν = 0

(1.61)

(1.62)

Adding and substracting (1.61) and (1.62) gives the condition:
.

x ± x′

2

=0

(1.63)

Known as the Visaroro constraints, and they are the analog of the Gauss
law in the string case.

9

1.6. LIGHT-CONE COORDINATES

1.6

Light-cone coordinates

Define the light-cone coordinates as:
ξ± = τ ± σ

(1.64)

ds2 = −dτ 2 + dσ 2 = − (dτ + dσ) (dτ − dσ) = −dξ+ dξ−

(1.65)

The flat metric becomes:

Thus, the metric components are:
g++ = g−− = 0

,

g+− = g−+ = −

1
2

(1.66)

and we have:
∂± =

1
(∂τ ± ∂σ )
2

(1.67)

Then, the Polyakov action in the conformal gauge (1.56) may be writen as:
Z
S = 2T ηµν ∂+ xµ ∂− xν d2 ξ
(1.68)
The equations of motion from the Polyakov action (1.57) becomes:
.. µ

x − x′′µ = ∂τ ∂τ xµ − ∂σ ∂σ xµ = 0

(1.69)

(∂τ + ∂σ ) (∂τ xµ − ∂σ xµ ) = 0

(1.70)

(∂τ + ∂σ ) (∂τ − ∂σ ) xµ = 0

(1.71)

∂+ ∂− xµ = 0

(1.72)

The stress-tensor in light-coordinates is:

T++ =

T−− =

 .ν

1
1
.µ
ηµν ∂+ xµ ∂+ xν = ηµν x + x′µ x + x′ν = T00 + 2T10
2
2

 .ν
1
1
.µ
ηµν ∂− xµ ∂− xν = ηµν x − x′µ x − x′ν = T00 − 2T10
2
2

(1.73)

(1.74)

10

CHAPTER 1. CLASSICAL STRING THEORY

T+− = T−+ = 0

(1.75)

In these coordinates, the Energy-momentum conservation is given by:
1
1
∇α Tαβ = − (∂− T++ + ∂+ T−+ ) = − (∂+ T−− + ∂− T+− ) = 0
2
2

(1.76)

but using (1.75) we obtain:
∂− T++ = ∂+ T−− = 0

(1.77)

And finally, the Visaroro constraints (1.63) can be written as:

T−− =

1.7

1
ηµν ∂− xµ ∂− xν = 0
2

,

T++ =

1
ηµν ∂+ xµ ∂+ xν = 0
2

(1.78)

Boundary Conditions

In string theory there are three important types:
In the case of closed strings the world-sheet is a tube, and one should impose
periodicity in the spacial parameter σ. Usually the period is choosen to be π:
xµ (σ + π, τ ) = xµ (σ, τ )

(1.79)

For open strings the world-sheet is a strip. The conditions used are:
Neumann:

∂xµ
=0
∂σ

at σ = 0 or π

(1.80)

Dirichlet:

∂xµ
=0
∂τ

at σ = 0 or π

(1.81)

Neumann condition imply that no momentum flows off the ends of the string.
Dirichlet condition implies that the end points of the string are fixed in spacetime, and that they ends on a physical object called D−brane ( D stands for
Dirichlet).

11

1.8. OSCILLATOR EXPANSIONS

1.8

Oscillator expansions

As we have seen the equation of motion for the string is (1.57):
.. µ

x − x′′µ = 0

(1.82)

but we must treat each case of boundary condition separately:
1. Closed Strings
For closed strings the general solution of the two-dimensional wave equation is a sum of ’right’ movers and ’left’ movers:
xµ (σ, τ ) = xµR (τ − σ) + xµL (τ + σ)

(1.83)

This solution must satisfy the conditions:
• xµ (σ, τ ) is real

• xµ (σ + π, τ ) = xµ (σ, τ )
This condition can be solved in terms of Fourier series as:

xµR (τ − σ) =

xµL (τ + σ) =

1 µ
i X 1 µ −in(τ −σ)
1 µ
xo +
p (τ − σ) + √
α e
2
2πT
n n
4πT

(1.84)

n6=0

1 µ
1 µ
i X 1 µ −in(τ +σ)
xo +
p (τ + σ) + √
α
e e
2
2πT
n n
4πT

(1.85)

n6=0

where αµn and α
eµn are Fourier modes that must satisfy (in order to xµ (σ, τ )
to be real):
(αµn )† = αµ−n

and

(e
αµn )† = α
eµ−n

(1.86)

The center of mass coordinate xµ and the momentum pµ are real too, and
the factor :
ℓs = √

1
2πT

(1.87)

is called the fundamental string lenght scale. So, the solution is:

xµ (σ, τ ) = xµo +


1 µ
i X 1 µ inσ
αn e
+α

(1.89)

we can write in light-cone coordinates:

(1.90)

2. Open Strings

In the case of open strings we will use the Neumann boundary conditions:
∂xµ
=0
∂σ

at σ = 0 or π

(1.92)

Using the solution (1.83) with the expresion for right and left movers (1.84)
and (1.85) and substituing in the Neumann condition we get:
∂xµR
∂xµL

(1.95)

n6=0

Then we obtain:
peµ = pµ

α
eµn = αµn

(1.96)
(1.97)

This means that the right and left movers get mixed in the solution for
the open string. Now, using the boundary condition at σ = π we get:
∂xµR
∂xµL
∂xµ

(1.98)

(1.99)

1.9. CENTER OF MASS POSITION AND MOMENTUM
−√

1 X µ −in(τ +π)
1 X µ −in(τ −π)
αn e
+√
αn e
=0
4πT n6=0
4πT n6=0

1 X µ −inπ
√
− einπ = 0
αn e
4πT n6=0

(1.100)
(1.101)

Then, we get the condition:
e−inπ − einπ = 0

(1.102)

− 2i sin (nπ) = 0

(1.103)

So, n must be an integer. The solution now becomes:

xµ (τ, σ) = xµo +


pµ
i X 1 µ −inτ inσ
e
+ e−inσ
τ+√
αn e
πT
n
4πT

(1.104)

n6=0

xµ (τ, σ) = xµo +

i X 1 µ −inτ
pµ
τ+√
α e
2 cos (nσ)
πT
n n
4πT

(1.105)

n6=0

xµ (τ, σ) = xµo +

pµ
i X 1 µ −inτ
τ+√
α e
cos (nσ)
πT
n n
πT

(1.106)

n6=0

Defining again αµ0 = √1πT pµ we get:
∂± xµ (τ, σ) =

1 µ
1 X µ −in(τ ±σ)
p +√
αn e

Center of mass Position and Momentum

The position and momentum of the center of mass for the open and closed
strings can be calculated, and they are given by:

(1.112)

pµCM = pµ

(1.114)
(1.115)

We can see that xµo is the position of the center of mass at τ = 0 and it
moves as a free particle. The variables that describe the motion of the string
are xµo and pµ plus the collection of αµn . This means that the string moves as a
whole (center of mass) and vibrate in various modes.

1.10

Classical Visaroro Algebra

The equal-τ Poison Brackets for the xµ and their conjugate momenta Πµ =
.µ

TheVisaroro operators are defined as the Fourier modes of the Stress tensor.

{Lm , Ln }P B = −i (m − n) Lm+n

e operators are absent.
For the open string the L’s

(1.149)

(1.151)

Chapter 2

Bosonic String Quantization
There exist three aproaches to quantize classical strings:
1. Canonical Quantization:
In this aproach the classical variables become operators. Because of the
constraints there are two options:
(a) Covariant Quantization
This procedure quantize first and then impose the constraints as conditions on states in Hilbert space. Is named covariant because it
preserves the Lorentz invariace.
(b) Light-Cone Quantization
Here, the constraints are solved in the classical system, so it leaves
a smaller number of classical variables. Then they are quantized. In
this aproach the manifest Lorentz invariance is lost.
2. Path Integral Quantization
This way preserves the manifest Lorentz invarinace, but contains ghost
fields.

2.1

Covariant Canonical Quantization

In the canonical quantization the fields are replaced by operators, and the Poisson brackets are reemplazed by commutators following the rule:
{ , }P B −→ −i [ , ]
Following this rule, the relations (1.116)-(1.118) become:
19

(2.1)

20

CHAPTER 2. BOSONIC STRING QUANTIZATION

h
i
.ν
xµ (σ, τ ) , Π (σ ′ , τ ) = iη µν δ (σ − σ ′ )

(2.2)

[xµ (σ, τ ) , xν (σ ′ , τ )] = 0

(2.3)

h.µ
i
.ν
Π (σ, τ ) , Π (σ ′ , τ ) = 0

(2.4)

Or in terms of the oscillator we can write:
[αµm , ανn ] = [e
αµm , α
eνn ] = mη µν δm+n,0
[e
αµm , ανn ] = 0

(2.6)

[xµ0 , pν ] = iη µν

(2.7)

(2.5)

The first of this conditions can be written, absorbing the factor m as:
i
i h
h
(2.8)
ανn )† = η µν δm,n
eµm , (e
αµm , (ανn )† = α

In Quantum Mechanics the harmonic oscillator can be described using raising
and lowering operatos that satisfy the condition:



α, α† = 1

(2.9)
†

Then, we see that the expansion coefficients αµ−n = (αµn ) and αµn are raising
and lowering operators respectively. But there are one problem. Because of the
metric tensor sign: η 00 = −1 the time component of the oscillators has a minus
sign. this means that they create states of negative norm, and it makes the
quantum theory inconsistent. However, as we will see the classical condition
Tαβ = 0 will eliminate the negative-norm states from physical spectrum.
Since the system is now an infinite set of harmonic oscillators, we may define
the Hilbert space in a simple way. The ground-state is the one that is anihilated
by all the lowering operators, but since this state is not completly determined
by this, we use the center-of-mass momentum operator. Diagonalizing pµ the
states are caracterized by its momentum. So, the ground state may be written
as:
αm |0, pi = 0

∀m > 0

Other states are obtained by aplying the raising operators:
Y
αµ−1 |0, pi , αµ−2 |pi ,
αµm |0, pi
m

(2.10)

(2.11)

2.1. COVARIANT CANONICAL QUANTIZATION

2.1.1

21

Visaroro Operators

In order to define the Visaroro operators in the quantum system we have to
introduce the normal ordering operation that puts all positive frequency modes
(lowering operators) to the right of the negative frequency modes (raising operators).
With this definition the Visaroro operators are defined as :
Lm =

1X
: αm−n · αn :
2 n

(2.12)

and similarly for the closed string:

X
em = 1
:α
em−n · α
en :
L
2 n

(2.13)

From now on, for the closed string there are similar relations for the operators
em.
L
The only operator affected by the normal ordering is L0 :
L0 =

1
1X
α0 · α0 +
: α−n · αn :
2
2 n

L0 =

∞
X
1
α0 · α0 +
α−n · αn
2
n=1

(2.14)

(2.15)

Now, because of the arbitrariness in definig the normal ordering we have to
include a normal-ordering constant q in the expresion for L0 .
L0 −→ L0 − q

(2.16)

The visaroro algebra can be calculated using the definition of the operators,
and it gives ( for a detailed calculation see [4]):
[Lm , Ln ] = (m − n) Lm+n +


c
m m2 − 1 δm+n,0
12

(2.17)

Its important to note that there exist a difference between the operator
and the Poisson algebra. this diference is a c-number which depends on the
dimension of space-time, since in the case we have c = d. This term is called
the ”conformal anomaly term” and the cnstant c is in general called the ”central
charge”. This term is an inescapable consequence of the quantization, and is
because of this that the string theory depends so much on the dimension of
space-time.
The classical Visaroro constraints (1.63) cannot be imposed as operators
constraints Lm |ψi = 0, because (2.17) gives:

22

CHAPTER 2. BOSONIC STRING QUANTIZATION

hψ| [Lm , L−m ] |ψi = 2m hψ| L0 |ψi +


d
m m2 − 1 hψ| ψi 6= 0
12

(2.18)

Thus, the constraints are imposed as:
(L0 − q) |φi = 0
Lm |φi = 0

(2.19)

m>0

(2.20)

where |φi denotes a physical state. This is consistent with the classical
constraints because:
hφ′ | (Lm − qδm,0 ) |φi = 0

for all m

(2.21)

As we will see, the constraint for L0 is a generalization of the Klein-Gordon
equation since it contains a term with p2 = −∂ · ∂ and a term that determines
the mass of the state.

2.1.2

Bosonic String Spectrum

Open String.
Using the form of L0 given by (2.15), the constraint (2.19) gives:
X
1
α0 · α0 +
α−n · αn = q
2
n

X
1
α0 · α0 = − α−n · αn + q
2
n

X
1 µ
p pµ = − α−n · αn + q
2πT
n

(2.22)
(2.23)
(2.24)

And using the mass-shell condition pµ pµ = −m2 , we have:
1
m2 = N − q
2πT
where is defined the level-number operator as:
X
N=
α−n · αn

(2.25)

(2.26)

n

Now, we will set q = 1 since this value is necessary for a consistent theory
(as we will se later). Since each α−n · αn has eiegnvalues 0, 1, 2, 3, ... etc. then

2.1. COVARIANT CANONICAL QUANTIZATION

23

the number operator also has values 0, 1, 2, .... The ground state, |0, pi is given
by N = 0 . So we have:
1
m2 = −1
(2.27)
2πT
This state corresponds to a Tachyon (since pµ is space-like). This particle
may cause a vacuum unstability, then it is not possible in a consisten quantum
theory. Anyway, we will not worry about it now and will continue with the
spectum analisis.
The first excited state has N = 1 and (2.25) gives m = 0. To obtain this
sate we need:
|φi = ξµ αµ−1 |0, pi

(2.28)

where ξ µ is the polarization vector for a massless spin-1 particle. Now, the
Visaroro constraint gives:
L1 |φi = 0

(2.29)

ξµ L1 αµ−1 |0, pi = 0

(2.30)

Since the operators αm (m > 0) anihilates the ground-state, L1 has just the
contributions:
!
1X
: α1−n · αn : αµ−1 |0, pi = 0
(2.31)
ξµ
2 n
1
ξµ (α0 · α1 + α1 · α0 ) αµ−1 |0, pi = 0
2

(2.32)

ξµ (α0 )ν αν1 αµ−1 |0, pi = 0

(2.33)



ξµ (α0 )ν αµ−1 αν1 + η µν |0, pi = 0

ξµ (α0 )ν αµ−1 αν1 |0, pi + ξµ (α0 )ν η µν |0, pi = 0
µ

(2.34)
(2.35)

ξµ (α0 ) |0, pi = 0

(2.36)

1
ξµ √ pµ |0, pi = 0
πT

(2.37)

ξµ pµ |0, pi = 0

(2.38)

24

CHAPTER 2. BOSONIC STRING QUANTIZATION
Then , the Visaroro constraint implies that ξµ must satisfy:
pµ ξµ = 0

(2.39)

This condition ensures that the spin is transversely polarized, so there are
just d − 2 independient polarization states.
The second excited state, with N = 2 , has:
1
m2 = 1
2πT

(2.40)

The most general state is a superposition :

|φi = ξµ αµ−2 + λµν αµ−1 αν−1 |0, pi

(2.41)

And again, the Visaroro constraints

L1 |φi = L2 |φi = 0

(2.42)

restrict the values of ξµ and λµν .
Closed String.
For the closed string we have the conditions:
(L0 − q) |φi = 0

(2.43)

(2.44)


e 0 − q |φi = 0
L

the sum of this conditions gives:


e 0 − 2q |φi = 0
L0 + L
So;

X

e0 · α

(2.45)

(2.46)

n

X

1 µ
p pµ = − α−n · αn −
α
e−n · α
en + 2q
πT
n
n

(2.48)

Using the mass-shell condition pµ pµ = −m2 , we have:
1 2
e − 2q
m =N +N
πT

(2.49)

2.1. COVARIANT CANONICAL QUANTIZATION
where the level-number operators are:
N=

X

α−n · αn

(2.50)

α

(2.51)

n

n

e=
N

X

The difference between (2.43) and (2.44) gives:


e 0 |φi = 0
L0 − L

(2.52)

Then we have the level-matching condition:
e0
L0 = L

(2.53)

X
X
1
1
α0 · α0 +
e0 · α
e0 +
α−n · αn = α
α
e−n · α
en
2
2
n
n
X
n

α−n · αn =

X
n

e
N =N

α
e−n · α
en

(2.54)
(2.55)
(2.56)

The closed string states are then the tensor product of left moving and right
moving states subject to the level matching condition. Then, the ground state
for the closed string is (without displaying the momuentum of the state):
|0i ⊗ |0i

(2.57)

e = 0, then, setting q = 1 we obtain:
Since in the ground state has N = N

1
m2 = −2
(2.58)
2πT
Again we obtain a spin 0 tachyon that makes the theory unststable.
The first excited state is:

eν−1 |0i
|φi = ξµν αµ−1 |0i ⊗ α

(2.59)

This state has m2 = 0. Again the Visaroro constraints
e 1 |φi = 0
L1 |φi = L

(2.60)

pµ ξµν = 0

(2.61)

restricts the possible values of the polarization to:

26

CHAPTER 2. BOSONIC STRING QUANTIZATION

This kind of tensor gives three distinct spin states: the symmetric part
encodes a massless spin-2 particle (gµν ), the antisymmetric part is a massless
antisymmetric tensor gauge field Bµν = −Bνµ ; and finally there is encoded also
an scalar field Φ.

Conclusion
We have described some of the basic ideas of the 26-dimensional bosonic string
theory. There exist different kinds of bosonic strings, but all of them are sick,
because in each case the spectra contains a tachyon. This means that the
vacuum state is unstable, and it is still an open problem.The most remarkable
feature of string theories is their dimensionality. Here we have seen that 26
dimensions are needed and there is no consistent explication of why this number
is prefered.
Anyway the study of this toy model give a better understanding of the
different process and features that the final theory should or should not have,
and its a necesary step for the study of more elaborated models, sucha as the
Superstings.

27

28

CONCLUSION

Bibliography
[1] Berkovits, N. An Introduction to Superstring Theory and its Duality Symmetries. Proceedings for the First School on Field Theory and Gravitation.
Vitória, Brasil. 1997.
[2] Green, M. Schwarz J. and Witten, E. Superstring Theory. (2 Volumes) Cambridge University Press.U.K. 1987.
[3] Kiritsis, E. Introduction to Superstring Theory. Lectures presented at the
Catholic University of Leuven and at the University of Padova. 1996-1997.
[4] Scherk, J. An Intorduction to the Theory of Dual Models and Strings. Rev.
Mod. Phys. 47-1. (1975)
[5] Schwarz, J. Introduction to Superstring Theory. Lectures presented at the
NATO Advanced Study Institue on Techniques and Concepts of High Energy
Physics. St. Croix, Virgin Islands. June 2000.

29
